Description: Rim and upper body sherd of Corinthian Conventionalizing pottery convex pyxis; interior: glazed black at rim, reserved below; exterior: streaky black around rim, raised fillet at junction with shoulder with black band below; painted decoration consisting of parts of horizontal and upright palmettes.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd belongs to the same vase as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.1245 and Unnumbered 41. For the shape and style, see Payne (1931), p. 331 for a pyxis with convex sides and cylindrical handles (Cat. Nos. 1493-7 and 1553). For parallels regarding the palmette decoration, see #1047a and 1065 in A.G. Newhall Stillwell and J.L. Benson, Corinth: The Potter's Quarter: Vol. XV, Part III (1984).
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (Catalogue no. 1491)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 72, pl. VI, no. 25)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.325) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
